questions.text: A 50-year-old patient complains of blurring of vision, which increases gradually along with occipital headaches. His RR is 16 cycles per min; BP is 150/90 mmHg sugar levels are normal. He has a history of CAD and medication with Atorvastatin and beta blockers and no family history of such events. His fundus findings are as below. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypertensive Retinopathy He has a high BP and headache, and the finding shows Salu’s sign which is seen in stage 2 hypertensive retinopathy . Pathogenesis - 3 factors play a role in pathogenesis Vasoconstriction Arteriosclerotic changes Increased vascular permeability Fundus changes that occur in patients with severe hypertension Clinican presentation include changes of Retinopathy Choroidopathy Optic neuropathy

Highyeild:

Clinically hypertensive fundus changes can be described as Chronic hypertensive retinopathy Malignant /acute hypertensive retinopathy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . is not possible as pt. have normal blood sugar Option: C . He doesn’t have any family history, and also pigmentary changes are not seen Option: D . It’s an ophthalmic emergency , and there is sudden DOV , and a cherry red spot is not seen.

Extraedge:

Fundus Changes: Salu’s Sign: deflection of veins at A-V Crossing Bonnet sign: banking of veins distal to A-V Crossing Gunn sign: tapering of veins on either side of the crossing.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the physician because of an itchy rash on her leg 3 days after she returned from a camping trip with her grandchildren. Examination shows a linear, erythematous, maculopapular rash on the left lower extremity. Treatment with a drug is begun that is also effective for motion sickness. One hour later, she reports a dry mouth. This adverse effect is most likely mediated through which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antagonism at acetylcholine receptors First-generation antihistamines , in addition to their H1-receptor antagonist action, also have potent acetylcholine receptor blocking action. AChRs are part of the parasympathetic nerve supply of the body. As saliva is secreted secondary to parasympathetic stimulation, antagonism at AChRs results in dry mouth, as seen in this patient.

Highyeild:

Other common anticholinergic effects include decreased sweating, tachycardia (unopposed sympathetic activity on the heart), blurring of vision for near objects (loss of accommodation reflex and mydriasis), urinary retention and constipation (loss of parasympathetic-mediated sphincter relaxation and peristalsis), and drowsiness.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Some antihistamines (e.g., cyproheptadine) have a serotonin receptor antagonistic action in addition to H1 receptor antagonism. However, serotonin plays no role in salivary secretion, so serotonin receptor antagonism is not responsible for the dry mouth this patient experiences after consuming the drug. Option: C. Agonism at β1-adrenergic receptors in the salivary gland stimulates salivary protein secretion and to a lesser extent, also fluid secretion, and thus would not cause the dry mouth seen in this patient. Catecholamines can activate β1-adrenergic receptors, but antihistamines do not affect Option: D. Drugs that antagonize H1 histamine receptors (antihistamines) are commonly used to treat pruritic rashes since histamine release in subcutaneous tissue triggers itching and localized vasodilation. Although this patient has a pruritic rash, histamine plays no role in salivary secretion, meaning histamine receptor antagonism is not responsible for this patient's dry mouth.

Extraedge:

Pharmacological effects of histamine: Histamine promotes (intestinal and bronchiolar ) smooth muscle contraction, which is an H1 receptor-mediated effect. Histamine significantly increases gastric acid and gastric pepsin secretion, which is an H2 receptor-mediated effect Vasodilation of arteriole and precapillary sphincters, which is an H1 and H2 receptor-mediated effect

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife noticed his left eye looks smaller than his right. He has had worsening left shoulder and arm pain for 3 months. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows left-sided ptosis. The pupils are unequal but reactive to light; when measured in dim light, the left pupil is 3 mm, and the right pupil is 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ophthalmologic symptoms?

options.label: D
options.text: Aneurysm of the Posterior Cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Compression of the Stellate ganglion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Compression of the Stellate ganglion Horner syndrome (HS) is a neurological disorder characterized by a symptom triad of miosis, partial ptosis, and facial anhidrosis, of which this patient has the former two symptoms. In a heavy smoker , symptoms of Horner syndrome combined with ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain concern a Pancoast tumor. Compression of the stellate ganglion by a Pancoast tumor can lead to Horner syndrome via injury of preganglionic sympathetic fibers. Superior sulcus tumors can infiltrate neighboring structures and cause additional symptoms, known as Pancoast syndrome.

Highyeild:

This patient's shoulder and arm pain are likely symptoms of Pancoast syndrome, which also includes atrophy of the arm and hand muscles and possibly superior vena cava syndrome and hoarseness due to compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Cavernous sinus thrombosis can result in Horner syndrome due to compression of postganglionic sympathetic neurons. However, cavernous sinus thrombosis has additional symptoms that are absent in this case, such as headache, photophobia, proptosis, and other cranial nerve palsies (commonly CN VI). In addition, cavernous sinus thrombosis is most commonly caused by ascending infection from the face or sinuses, signs of which are absent This patient's arm and shoulder pain would likewise not be explained by cavernous sinus thrombosis Option: C . Infiltration of the cervical plexus, typically by neck soft tissue tumors or lymph node metastases, manifests with pain in the neck and submandibular area, as well as sensory loss in the C2, C3, and C4 dermatomes, symptoms which this patient does not have. It would not be expected to cause Horner syndrome or shoulder and arm pain. Option: D . Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery could compress CN III, which carries parasympathetic fibers to the pupillary sphincter and ciliary muscle, and motor fibers to the levator palpebrae superioris and all extraocular muscles except for the superior oblique muscle and the lateral rectus muscle. Such an aneurysm would result in ptosis, which this patient has, diplopia, a fixed and dilated pupil, and a down-and-out gaze , which are not present here. Rather than mydriasis, this patient has miosis. Furthermore, if such an aneurysm were symptomatic, it would manifest with a headache rather than the shoulder and arm pain seen here.

Extraedge:

The most common cause of Pancoast syndrome is NSCLC , for which this patient is at risk because of his smoking history.

questions.text: Mrs. Rajni, a 50-year-old woman with a 10-day history of nasal discharge, a headache that increases on bending down, and pain over the medial canthus, now presents to the outpatient department with high-grade fever, chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On further inquiry, it is brought to light that the proptosis began in the right eye, and since yesterday, the left eye has also been affected. On examination, her pulse rate is 56 beats per minute; her BP is 150/96 mm of Hg, and her temperature is 102F. There is periorbital edema, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia. The pupillary response is sluggish. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis The given clinical scenario, with recurrent episodes of headache and pain over the medial canthus and repeated use of nasal decongestants, suggests that the patient was suffering from sinusitis which has most likely resulted in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Fever, Signs of raised intracranial pressure- Headache (gradual or thunderclap), vomiting, and papilloedema.

Highyeild:

Eye signs - Early abducent nerve involvement causing lateral rectus palsy (since it runs through the cavernous sinus ) Later involvement of oculomotor and trochlear nerve causing palsy (as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus), Proptosis, Severe supraorbital pain, Absence of corneal sensation, Dilated pupil. Focal neurological deficits Focal or generalized seizures Altered mental status.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A .Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint. Option: B .Orbital pseudotumor, also called an idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome, presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, and conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids. Option: C . Orbital cellulitis presents unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

Extraedge:

Investigation using brain MRI or MR venography should be done urgently. Following early diagnosis, management of cavernous sinus thrombosis typically includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics and anticoagulants.
